maybe the trade-off is worth it. slow and steady innovation at L1 gives predictability, which buys time for the right innovations to get absorbed.

1126164490079305728.text:
naturally, nothing works forever. at some point, Ethereum will need to address state bloat and other issues just to keep operating as expected.

and in lieu of a formal governance system, making these changes will no doubt be more difficult. but is it an insurmountable problem?

1126164488770719745.text: during time(t)—the time where the protocol continues to operate as expected—innovation can continue at Layer 2, devs can build apps on top of pooled security & liquidity, and meanwhile, other platforms will run the experiments to de-risk new CS and governance innovations.

1126164488049299458.text:
so, in the short term, could protocol ossification due to lack of formal governance be a good thing? 

theres an argument that so long as a platform retains base functionality, foregoing experimental governance in exchange for predictable operation is a reasonable trade-off

1094990179805335555.text: Answers to these Qs will dictate whether blockchain computers are the tool that unlock a new wave of innovation in stakeholder-driven enterprises, which Fink is suggesting CEOs start building today.

1094990178752565248.text: What second order effects do software/contract automation unlock for human governance processes? Which ingredients from legacy stakeholder enterprises are still necessary and applicable here (e.g. identity, mgmt hierarchy, arbitration, rule of law?)

1094990177670443008.text: OTOH, it's not yet clear what exactly smart contracts unlock for subjective human governance. Thus far, the “strong” form of blockchain computing has been mostly limited to autonomous, deterministic or algorithmic governance processes, not subjective human ones.

1076885928356900869.text: No doubt standardization is helpful for developers, but it is instantiation of standards that drives network effects. In IP it's the shared address space. You can conform to the IP standard, but instantiate a different network (e.g. China).

standards != network effects.
standards = interoperability; only one input to developer NFXs.

shared state is a stronger, direct driver of dev+user NFXs—its what’s unique about crypto networks.

web 2.0 has standards, but network effects emerges from data. that state is siloed.

price stability → accessibility & adoption → more tokenized assets → diversified collateral base for $DAI  ↺

1044268716400107523.text: 9/ Among this group are some of the sharpest ppl we’ve met in crypto, including @RuneKek and @RealZandy who founded the project. We've been consistently impressed by the team's technical ingenuity, execution, and community building.

1044268715380891648.text:
8/ Maker is a DAO (decentralized autonomous organization):

Instead of a central entity, Maker is governed by $MKR token holders; akin to “miners” of the network, they do the work of keeping the system stable, secure and growing.

1044268714244268032.text:
7/ Maker is a truly novel application that leverages trust, the unique primitive of blockchain computers:

Instead of intermediaries, users trust transparent, autonomous code. This compression of trust can scale global collaboration:https://twitter.com/jessewldn/status/1044019662629986304 …

1044268713371820032.text:
6/ Maker is a two-sided marketplace:

On one side, users seek leverage or liquidity from digital assets; this credit system is denominated in $DAI.

On the other side, $DAI users simply seek a price stable currency. They never need to interact with the underlying credit system.

1044268711253688320.text: 4/ Like other cryptocurrencies, Dai is borderless, trustless, and accessible to anyone with an internet connection. It can be used for payments, savings, or as a base for other applications like lending, derivatives, prediction markets and more.

1044268710343532544.text: 3/ Dai is created when digital assets are deposited to Maker smart contracts. It is a credit system where Dai is issued as a loan against the deposit. The amount of Dai in circulation is a function of the total USD-value of deposited collateral.

1044268709404016640.text:
2/ there are 3 common approaches to building stablecoins: fiat backed, algorithmic ("seignorage shares") models, and digital asset backed (the post describes each.)

Maker’s stablecoin, $DAI, is digital asset backed and pegged to USD.
